text: President Barack Obama is criticized on the left and right for his response to the 18-year-old murder of Michael Brown by the Ferguson police officer, Mo. "Suddenly now, you get this uprising and what's the answer? Well, as we know, you're sending a statement about Brother Robin Williams' death before you send a statement about Brother Michael Brown." We wondered whether Obama had commented on Williams' death before addressing the Brown case. It's important to note that the dead are not the same. Williams was world famous, and his death news spread fast. His death did not provoke protests or issues of police misconduct. Data from political leaders and the White House when celebrities die are often quick and unchallenged. In the meantime, Brown was mostly an unknown figure to the world when he was killed in August 9, and it took a long time to spread the story of his death. For example, the New York Times did not put a story about Brown or Ferguson on its first page until August 12. But as comparisons go, West has valid facts.
